description: Graphical displays; one- and two-sample confidence intervals; one- and two-sample hypothesis tests; one- and two-way ANOVA; simple and multiple linear least-squares regression; nonlinear regression; variable selection; logistic regression; categorical data analysis; goodness-of-fit tests. A methodology course. This course does not have business applications but has significant overlap with STAT 101 and 102.
name: STATISTICAL INFERENCE

values.comments:
Statistics 431 covers graphical displays, one- and two-sample confidence intervals, one- and two-sample hypothesis tests, one- and two-way ANOVA, simple and multiple linear least-squares regression, nonlinear regression, variable selection, logistic regression, categorical data analysis, and goodness-of-fit tests. This is a methodology course.  It does not have business applications, but does have significant overlap with STAT 101 and 102.

This course received mixed reviews.  A few students spoke positively of lectures that “were extremely clear and organized.”  However, several students had a “bad experience with the course.”  A few of these students described the class as “boring” or “disappointing,” and several said either that “there were not nearly enough examples in class” or that the “amount of material and equations made it more of a copying lecture, which detracted from the students’ ability to actually understand the material in class.”  A few students also complained that they were required to use R (a statistics software) without being taught how to do so in class.  This “was difficult for students,” especially those “with no programming background.”

Reviews of Professor Fox were also mixed.  Several students described her as “boring,” and some elaborated to say that “it sometimes felt like she was just copying her notes on the board, rather than actually teaching and explaining.”  However, several students did note that this was her first semester teaching.  Of these students, a few complimented her for “improving during the semester” and being “very receptive to questions and changes.”  Additionally, some students felt that she was already “very articulate and was overall very good at teaching.”    

Grading in this course is based on weekly problems sets and two exams.  A couple of students commented that the problem sets were either “difficult” or “fairly time-consuming.”  Additionally, a few students said that the midterm “was very difficult, as it was far too long.”  However, they acknowledged that this would likely improve as the professor gained more experience.  STAT 430 is a prerequisite.  STAT 431 can be taken in combination with STAT 430 to fulfill the statistics requirements in the Wharton core.
